Overview & Usage

Example Task

The LickWithhold task is an example of a head fixing task.

Upon initializing, AutoHeadFix will wait for a mouse to enter the headfixing area, with a prompt Waiting for a mouse... For testing, we can use a spare RFID tag to simulate mouse entry.

After the ID is detected, AutoHeadFix will wait on the ContactCheck, which in this case is a BeamBreak (AHF_ContactCheck_BeamBreak). For testing, simply break the beam manually.

Upon beam break, the camera and brainlight will turn on and the trial will commence. The trial will be selected based on the mouse level, as described in AHF_Stimulator.

Code Structure

Everything is called from __main__2.py, which initializes an AHF_Task.

AHF_Task contains a reference to one instance of each class:

AHF_HeadFixer
AHF_Stimulus
AHF_Stimulator
AHF_Rewarder
AHF_Reader
AHF_Camera
AHF_ContactCheck
AHF_BrainLight
AHF_Trigger
AHF_LickDetector
AHF_DataLogger
AHF_Notifier
AHF_Subjects

The roles and definitions of each class can be found at AutoHeadFix Code Documentation.

Each module is implemented by a specific subclass, depending on the task configuration (see below). Existent task descriptions can be found at AHF_Stimulator.

There are often one or more subclasses available for each module, named AHF_[class]_[subclass]. For example, AHF_Stimulator has subclasses AHF_Stimulator_LEDs, AHF_Stimulator_Lever, AHF_Stimulator_LickWithhold, AHF_Stimulator_Rewards. For the LickWithhold task, AHF_Stimulator is implemented by AHF_Stimulator_LickWithhold, AHF_Camera is implemented by AHF_Camera_PiCam.

For every task, __main__2.py performs the same loop. First, the database is initialized; however, as of right now, the database is not working. Next the task is initialized from AHF_Task. The main loop is then started, where the TagReader waits for a mouse, fixes the mouse with the HeadFixer, then initiates the Stimulator` to handle task-spefic logic.

On keyboard interrupt, the program enters the AutoHeadFix Manager menu.
